tactics.description: The initial access tactic represents techniques that adversaries use to gain an initial foothold within a network.
The execution tactic represents techniques that result in execution of adversary-controlled code on a local or remote system.
The persistence tactic contains techniques that adversaries use to maintain access to systems across restarts, changed credentials, and other interruptions.
The privilege escalation tactic contains techniques that adversaries use to gain higher-level permissions on a system or network.
The defense evasion tactic consists of techniques that adversaries use to avoid detection throughout their compromise.
The credential access tactic represents techniques used by adversaries to steal credentials like account names and passwords.
The discovery tactic contains techniques that adversaries use to gain knowledge about the system and network.
The lateral movement tactic contains techniques that adversaries use to enter and control remote systems on a network.
The collection tactic contains techniques used to gather information and sources of information of interest to the adversary.
The exfiltration tactic refers to techniques that adversaries may use to steal data from your network.
The command and control tactic represents how adversaries communicate with systems under their control within a victim network.
The impact tactic consists of techniques that adversaries use to disrupt availability or compromise integrity by manipulating business and operational processes.

techniques.description: Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems.
Adversaries may send spearphishing emails with a malicious attachment in an attempt to gain access to victim systems.
Adversaries may send spearphishing emails with a link to a malicious website in an attempt to gain access to victim systems.
Adversaries may attempt to exploit public-facing applications to gain initial access.
Adversaries may leverage external remote services as a point of initial access.
Adversaries may obtain and abuse credentials of existing accounts as a means of gaining initial access.
Adversaries may use brute force techniques to gain access to accounts.
Adversaries may use a password spraying technique for authentication brute force.
Adversaries may use stolen credential lists to attempt to gain access to victim systems.
Adversaries may enumerate files and directories or may search in specific locations of a host or network share for certain information.
Adversaries may scan for services running on hosts to find opportunities for lateral movement or information gathering.
Adversaries may exfiltrate data using a different protocol than that of the existing command and control channel.
Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate web service to exfiltrate data.
Adversaries may exfiltrate data to a cloud storage service.
Adversaries may abuse command and script interpreters to execute commands, scripts, or binaries.
Adversaries may use scheduled tasks to maintain persistence and execute programs at system startup or at specific times.
Adversaries may inject code into processes to evade process-based defenses and potentially elevate privileges.
Adversaries may use obfuscation to hide artifacts of an intrusion from analysis.
Adversaries may use remote services to move laterally within a network.
Adversaries may collect emails from victims to gather information.
